articles.title: Introducing Horizontal Rules for <select>
articles.description: As of Chrome 119 and Safari 17, you can add <hr> elements into a list of select options as a way to visually break them up that differs from the <optgroup> approach. A beautiful coming together of two of the oldest HTML elements to create something new.
articles.author: Una Kravets (Chrome Developers)

articles.title: 🎨 Vectorpea: An Online Vector Editor
articles.description: Photopea is a popular online image editor that just celebrated its tenth birthday – what better way to celebrate than releasing a vector version? It’s not Adobe Illustrator yet, but there’s plenty to enjoy and you can export your creations as SVGs for your projects.
articles.author: Ivan Kuckir

articles.title: ▶  When 100 Developers Reproduce the Same Web Layout
articles.description: A popular web design YouTuber asked folks on his Discord to reproduce a ‘card’ layout however they wished. In this video, he analyzes the approaches taken which mostly break down between using grids and flexbox – though one plucky individual went with tables! (16 minutes.)
articles.author: Kevin Powell

articles.title: An Introduction to Web Sustainability
articles.description: What can designers and developers do to build a more sustainable web? Michelle explores the environmental impacts of web tech and looks at how to build greener sites.
articles.author: Michelle Barker

articles.title: The Three Cs: 🤝 Concatenate, 🗜️ Compress, 🗳️ Cache
articles.description: When serving and storing files on the web, Harry notes that there are a number of different things we need to take into consideration in order to balance ergonomics, performance, and effectiveness. This meaty post breaks these processes down into three: concatenating files on the server, compressing them over the network, and caching them at the other end.
articles.author: Harry Roberts

articles.title: Using ChatGPT for 'Smart Truncation' in Responsive Design?
articles.description: We’re not saying this is a great approach, but the idea of ‘responsive content’ (where the length of written content is adjusted to fit the viewing environment) is certainly intriguing.
articles.author: Mike Solomon

articles.title: No More 404
articles.description: Remy shares a neat solution to dreaded link rot that leans on archive․org's Wayback Machine.
articles.author: Remy Sharp

articles.title: Changing Colors in an SVG Element with CSS and JavaScript
articles.description: Almost everything inside an inline SVG image is up for modification using CSS and JavaScript.
articles.author: Kirupa Chinnathambi

articles.title: Generating Tailwind Width Configs with Generative AI
articles.description: Tasking ChatGPT, Github Copilot, and Phind with generating width configs ended with mixed results, with just one taking the golden ratio into account.
articles.author: Lucian Ghinda

articles.title: ▶  Using CSS Custom Properties Like This is a Waste
articles.description: A little PSA from Kevin on how to simplify things when using CSS custom properties.
articles.author: Kevin Powell

articles.title: cccolor: A HEX, RGB and HSL Color Picker for HTML / CSS
articles.description: There are a lot of color pickers for designers, but this new one is neat with color values available to quickly copy to the clipboard as RGB, HSL, hex, or oklch.
articles.author: ffffffuel

articles.title: Color Contrast Accessibility Tools with Examples
articles.description: Sticking to the topic of color, here are a few ways to approach checking that the contrast between colors is good from an accessibility perspective.
articles.author: Whitney Lewis

articles.title: Beer CSS: Build Material-Based Designs in Record Time
articles.description: A CSS framework based on Material Design 3 whose name is inspired by a German ‘beer purity law’ where beer should have only the essential ingredients. Similarly, Beer CSS only has settings, elements, and helpers.
articles.author: Beer CSS

articles.title: Ruffle: A Flash Player Emulator
articles.description: Built in Rust, Ruffle targets both desktop and the web using WebAssembly. Time for a Flash renaissance? 😆 Of course there are demos.
articles.author: Ruffle

articles.title: 404 Illustrations: Trendy 404 Images
articles.description: There’s a handful of fun images that may well work on your Page Not Found pages here.
articles.author: Kapwing

articles.title: imgly/background-removal: Remove Backgrounds From Images
articles.description: A way to remove backgrounds from images directly in the browser (yes, there’s a live demo) without relying on a third party service. It relies on a large pre-trained model to do this, however, and is GPL licensed.
articles.author: img․ly

articles.description: Chrome 117 has introduced text-wrap: pretty – a new setting for the text-wrap property that handles typographic widows and orphans.
💞 What Does Happily Ever After Look Like? is a beautiful piece of modern web design (and a cool data-led look at romance novel book covers too).
Ricky Onsman has shared a thorough list of newsletters and blogs focused on digital accessibility.
We've mentioned the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines a lot, as WCAG 2.2 came out recently. If you want to get up to speed, Geoff Graham has a roundup of WCAG 2.2 explainers.
Safari Technology Preview 181 landed just after we sent last week's issue. It adds support for content-visibility.
